Interdisciplinary Research Center for Hydrogen and Energy Storage and Chemical Engineering Department King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals Dhahran 31261 Saudi Arabia Sequel to the future challenges identified in the energy indicators, the exploration of algae-biomass resources increasingly becoming an issue of interest. Algae-derived oils are accordingly considered as alternative fuels with great future prospects. However, their direct utilization is scientifically difficult due to associated complex compositions. So far, hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of the oils is increasingly viewed as the reliable upgrading process for deriving high quality fuels. The paper therefore explored and critically examined substantial literature on the updates related to catalyst design and testing for HDO, the influence of oil production techniques on its susceptibility to HDO, effects of parameters such as catalyst sulfidation, modification to phosphides, nature of support systems and preparation versus reaction conditions. In addition to highlights on reaction mechanisms, the paper also discussed the effect of hydrothermal treatment on HDO catalyst stability and provided insights into areas for further investigations. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Algae-derived oils Hydrodeoxygenation Metal phosphides sulfidation 1 Introduction Sequel to the numerous challenges attributed to the fossil fuels that include increasing global consumption, price instability, serious environmental degradation and overall reserves declination [1–6], the exploration of abundant biomass resources for energy consumption is necessary [7–11]. Unlike fossil fuels and their energy derivatives, biomass represents a collection of plant and/or animal resources that could be valorized for energy applications or other industrial uses. Specifically, the biomass resources can include agricultural-based outputs and residues (covering woods, crops and allied wastes) as well as animal products [12–16]. The biomass resources could be upgraded by different scientific and engineering processes such as gasification for synthesis gas production [17,18], transesterification for biodiesel synthesis [19–21], pyrolysis and Fischer Tropsch for liquid hydrocarbons generation [22,23], and a range of many other valorization methodologies of industrial relevance [24–26]. Among biomass resources, algae feedstock has attracted wide global acceptance as energy resources [27]. Scientifically, the algae represent a wide group of both aquatic and non-aquatic organisms with substantial capabilities to produce oxygen via photosynthesis like the green plants. While the seaweeds were generally common algae species to most researchers, records have established numerous other species of global economic importance [28–30]. One major interesting factor considered by the industry was the market analysis of the algae feedstock and algae products. There are clear statistical evidences that the global market for algae will grow at the overall rate of 4.2% between 2018 and 2025 [31]. This can account for at least 3451 USD in generated funds, which is a huge growth compared to 2017 and previous years. Several factors can be attributed to this increment. The projected rise in global human population accounted to rise in food consumption and consequently increased the associated algae products. Persistent increase in the demands for consumables energy and allied additives cannot be neglected in this perspective. Production costs and technological compatibilities were additional positive factors of industrial interest that account for algae market growth. Owing to these factors, as illustrated in Fig. 1 , food products and hydrocolloids will be responsible for 4.1 and 3.8% cumulative growth, respectively [31]. Accordingly, the green algae products and fuels will experience a speedy growth of 6.0% within the forecast period (i.e. 2018–2025). Among the global regions, countries in the Asia-Pacific would achieve the highest market growth of 6.2% within the period [31,32]. Different research groups have demonstrated the production of biofuels (including liquid hydrocarbons) from algae as very prospective compared to the other biomass-based oil crops. Algae species are numerously abundant and can practically be grown in almost all global environments with limited inconsistencies and without resource to the food-land. The level of oil content that can be extracted had been assigned at 100 times higher than other regular energy crops under similar factors. Statistically, more than 20,000 gallons of oil could be derived per acre of farmland cultivated [33]. This amount was really courageous and attractive to the developers. Fig. 2 provides a typical comparative analysis of the yield of liquid fuel from algae compared to some common agricultural crops. While most of these crops can produce a maximum of 1000 gallons per acre, algae species can produce up to 5000 gallons, which is economically very attractive [33]. Despite these advantages, the fundamental procedures for oil extraction from algae have been established and proved to be environmentally sustainable. Certainly, oils derived from algae were associated with a range of O-bearing compounds that include the triglyceride esters, fatty acids, traces of alcohols (including phenols) and the lipids [34–37]. Therefore, to upgrade these compounds into corresponding liquid hydrocarbon fuels or other derivatives, the O-species must be appropriately removed. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) was a long technology that adopted from petroleum refineries to remove O-species during petroleum refining and/or upgrading [38–40]. It usually proceeds with incorporation of a suitable catalyst (e.g. sulfur-modified NiMo) at high H2-pressure of 20 MPa and temperatures in the range of 250–400 °C [41–44]. At the end of the HDO reaction, oxygen species was rejected as water vapor and naphtha hydrocarbons generated as the main products (see Eq. (1)). Recent interest in algae valorization has witnessed the extension of the HDO process in algae and other biomass-derived oils upgrading. In fact, the yield of liquid hydrocarbons from HDO of biomass could be up to 60% depending on the choice of reaction conditions, reactor design and the quality of oil to be hydrodeoxygenated [45,46]. In addition to oxygen, bio-crude oil of algae also contained other heteroatoms such as nitrogen and sulfur (total heteroatoms of 10–20 wt.%) which would lead to formation of SOx and NOx after combustion [47,48]. Moreover, some metal impurities such as magnesium, sodium, calcium, iron and etc. were also existed in the algae crude oil [49]. (1) R 2 O ( l ) + 2 H 2 ( g ) → H 2 O ( g ) + 2 RH ( 1 ) Although there are other oxygen removal options applicable to the algae derived oils, the HDO process has been given good attention in the recent times due to a number of advantages [50]. The high H2-pressure in the reaction has the advantage of insitu coke hydrogenation and therefore hinders catalyst deactivation by carbonaceous deposits. Similarly, hydrocarbon products with comparable quality to the conventional tranportation fuels could be achieved. The heterogeneous nature of the reaction system accordingly infer that environmental and economic difficulties can be appreciably handled. Although the application of sulfur-modified NiMo, CoMo, NiCo and other supported catalysts had been prioritised, recent investigations include the incorporation of Pt, Rh and Re-based systems were also reported [51,52]. However, the expensive nature of these precious metals may limit their economic sustainability. Consequent to the great shift in the exploration of algae-biomass for fuels application and the projected market growth, the current review targets a critical analysis of key issues in the hydrodeoxygenation (i.e. HDO) of algae-derived oils. The specific area of interest includes an analysis of the procedures for algae oils production, the role of HDO catalysts, attributes of the sulfidation process and the derivable benefits of phosphorous additives (i.e. modification). In addition to the critical analysis of any update on the HDO mechanisms, the review will also discuss stability of the catalysts under steam/water conditions. Areas for further research consideration will accordingly be highlighted. 2 Algae-derived oils production One of the major important issue to be considered before designing the HDO reaction is the chemical composition of the algae oil. This composition was in turn dependent on the procedure adopted for deriving the oil. Generally, the techniques for algae oils extraction can be grouped into two; (1) the direct extraction from algae biomass and (2) the reaction methods. 2.1 Direct extraction methods Direct extraction of oils from algae species could be achieved in many ways ranging from pressing to ultrasonic-assisted extraction (see Fig. 4) [53–55]. The pressing method was conducted by the application of external pressures to break cells and extract oils from Algae. Alternatively, the milling process, which involved the application of grinding media and agitation to destruct the cells could be employed. Both pressing and milling technologies were applied together with solvent extraction in order to achieve high oil yield. Specifically, the solvent extraction method proceeded with sequential percolation of reduced-to-size algae feedstock in organic solvents such as hexane or alcohols to achieve high oil yield. A part from these physical extraction methods, supercritical fluid technique has been developed and proved to be efficient. In this regard, supercritical water or CO2 generated at certain temperatures and pressure conditions could be employed as solvent to extract large quantities of oil from algae biomass [56–58]. Other developed extraction procedures under evaluation include enzymatic, ultrasonic and osmotic shock methods [55,59,60]. The enzymatic process involved the use of enzymes to activate a rapid hydrolysis of algae cell walls in order to produce oil in a given solvent of interest. The ultrasonic process on the other hand, requires the introduction of ultrasonic waves to rupture algae cells and produce oil into a solvent [61,62]. In the case of osmotic shock method, the breakage of algae cell walls was accomplished by the application of osmotic pressure and the method was the most partly resolved so far. Generally, the direct extraction method was potential to extract around 99% of all the oil content in the algae biomass. They also have the advantages of non-energy intensiveness and the production of high-grade non-reduced oils [63–67]. The oils obtained via these methods have been characterized by possession of fatty esters, free fatty acids, proteins and partly decomposed carbohydrates. Because of the high purity, HDO processing of the oils derived via extraction could be achieved with less interference. 2.2 Reaction methods The second approach to algae-derived oils production was referred as “reaction methods” (see Fig. 4). These methods involved the reaction of algae biomass under catalytic or non-catalytic conditions to produce oil and other reaction products like biogas and biochar. Pyrolysis and hydrothermal liquefaction were the common reaction methods prioritized in the literature so far. Pyrolysis proceeded through chemical decomposition of algae biomass at high temperature and without the incorporation of air or oxygen [68,69]. Although atmospheric pressure (1 atm) could be sufficient, most pyrolysis reactions were accomplished at temperatures exceeding 400 °C. The irreversible process substantially changed the physical and chemical compositions of the algae feeds. The pyrolysis process could be classified into slow and fast methods. The slow pyrolysis method required several hours to complete and under low temperature (250–450 °C) [70–72]. This type of pyrolysis was not so useful for algae-derived oils production because the main reaction product was biochar and for this reason the process was otherwise called “carbonization”. The fast pyrolysis is accomplished in seconds and had been defined to produce up to 60% of algae-derived oils. It could be achieved at temperatures exceeding 500 °C and 1 atm pressure. In our earlier publication [22], we have substantially discussed the process of fast pyrolysis, catalytic systems involved and the influence of reaction parameters in producing desired fuel products. Therefore, this review will only cover key recent relevant updates. According to Anand et al. [73], and several other research groups [14,74–78], fast pyrolysis of algae biomass in the temperature range of 500–800 °C can produce oils with esters, alcohols, carboxylic acids and carbonyl compounds content in the range of 70–85%. Accordingly, traces of alkanes, alkenes and monoaromatics could be produced to less than 10%. However, the application of catalysts such as H-BEA and H-ZSM-5 zeolites or the modified acid oxides of ZrO2, CeO2 and TiO2 reduced the composition of the oxygenates in the algae oils significantly and increased the overall amount of hydrocarbon derivatives [79–82]. The non-catalytic process only required the introduction of heat to trigger bond ruptures in the algae biomass. On the other hand, the introduction of catalysts, activated several reactions such as decarboxylation, decarbonylation, isomerization and catalytic cracking (see Figs. 5 and 6). This way, long chain organic acids and alkanols in the generated algae oil were further cracked into lower molecular weight derivatives. Typically, the composition of heavier oxygenates could be reduced by more than 50% depend on the catalyst acidity-structure properties. For the zeolite catalysts, moderate acidity and development of hierarchical and nanoscale materials were important parameters to produce hydrocarbons in the algae oil. This has been attributed to the enhanced diffusion properties of the reaction products and the prevention of facile cracking. Algae oils produced via catalytic fast pyrolysis could be rich in BTEX compounds (i.e. benzene, toluene, ethylbenzenes and xylenes), which are very important components of a high-grade gasoline fuel [83,84]. Accordingly, the HDO of these oils could be achieved under mild reaction conditions, specifically due to low concentration of oxygenates. Hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL) of algae biomass was another low-to-moderate temperature conversion process for oils production [85]. The method had been attributed with high efficiency compared to the fast pyrolysis option. However, in a similar manner to pyrolysis, the HTL can be achieved under both catalytic and non-catalytic conditions. In most literature, HTL was viewed as the technology to upgrade algae or other biomass resources into liquid oils through the application of variable reaction conditions. Reaction temperatures in the range of 250–400 °C and pressures exceeding 10 MPa have so far been documented [86–89]. Unlike the pyrolysis which can be achieved in seconds, HTL reactions could normally be accomplished between 5 and 120 min [90,91]. Although the yield of reaction products can vary with the nature of algae species and the HTL conditions employed, the derivable products generally comprised of oil in the range of 20–65 wt.%. Other reaction products were C-, N- and O-bearing gases, the aqueous phase and solid residues [92,93]. All of these four phases can successfully be separated and analyzed and the end of the process. In Xu et al. [90], and our earlier publication [94], the benefits of algae HTL over other reaction methods such as pyrolysis had been documented. These include feasibility in the conversion of wet algae thereby eliminating additional energy requirements. Additionally, this production route produced at least 5% additional oil yield compared to pyrolysis and the removal of N- and P-bearing impurity compounds into the aqueous phase. This certainly reduced impurities in the desired algae oil phase as well as promoted the separation of water soluble inorganic salts and carboxylic acids. There are unanimous literature agreement that the choice of catalytic material was crucial in achieving yield and purity of oil from the algae biomass HTL [90,95,96]. Similarly, the process mechanism was dependent on whether the reaction was conducted using homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts. Water soluble catalysts based on carbonates (i.e. K2CO3 and Na2CO3), hydroxides such as KOH and NaOH and simple organic acids like formic and acetic acids have been reported to yield between 20 and 42 wt.% of algae oils [97,98]. On the other hand, the heterogeneous systems based on metals-modified oxides and zeolites could produce up to 65 wt.% of oils and regarded as thermodynamically and kinetically more feasible [99,100]. They were similarly very efficient in eliminating the anticipated environmental dangers of catalyst disposal at the end of the reaction cycle. Noble metals were identified to activate hydrogen at mild temperature, then open possibility for HDO at lower temperature. The work of Xu et al. [101], substantially explored the role of precious metals-based catalysts supported with C (i.e. Pd/C and Ru/C) on the net properties and composition of HTL-produced algae oils. The protein-rich (60.1%) chlorella sp. was subjected to HTL by incorporating ∼2.70 ml of water and 0.1 g catalyst at 350 °C. They found that the catalyst was effective in decreasing the concentration of water-soluble organic compounds from the algae oil due to associated cracking reactions. Specifically, the Pd/C catalyst degraded heavier amines and O-bearing compounds like alcohols into lighter derivatives. Table 1 provides a collection of literature updates on the application of various catalysts during algae liquefaction under hydrothermal conditions (i.e. the HTL). The results demonstrated that in addition to nature of the algae species, the choice of catalyst and reaction conditions were very important. Apparently, oil yields up to 66 wt.% could be derived at the optimal temperature range of 280–320 °C and reaction time exceeding 30 min. Generally, the catalytic reactions produced more yields of oil than the non-catalytic counterparts performed under the same conditions [102–105]. Multifunctional catalyst received growing interest recently as the possibility for one-pot HDO reaction under milder condition with easier tuning to the desired chemical product [106]. This multifunctional catalyst generally comprised of noble metals, promoter and acid support like zeolite. Researchers in this area are still on debate whether the reaction mechanism occurred via two-step reduction or multi-step cascade processes. These two pathways were derived as the zeolite facilitate dehydration of alcohol to alkenes in two step reduction, and the multifunctional active sites of noble metal, promoter and zeolite that can work simultaneously in HDO reaction through multi-step cascade process. This multifunctional catalyst could become an alternative to perform HDO reaction at low temperature, but the price of noble metals must be anticipated for further commercialization. Sub- and supercritical water were classified as green solvent and also hold potential for bio-oil upgrading. Sub- and supercritical water referred to condition at below and above water critical points (water critical points: T: 374 and P: 22.1 MPa), respectively. Toor et al. investigated bio-oil extraction from two types of algae at super- and sub-critical conditions [107]. The maximum bio-oil yield (34 and 46%) depended on the algae species, pressure and temperature. But, they confirmed that sub-critical water was more effective than supercritical water with rich protein in oil composition. In another study, supercritical water was confirmed to increase water soluble fraction in biocrude of algae and decreased heteroatoms content by 15% [108]. The supercritical condition also applicable for other organic solvent such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, etc. The utilization of supercritical methanol in extraction of bio-oil from algae was reported by Han et al. [109]. They compared non-catalytic and catalytic process with several metal oxides catalyst such as ZrO2, MnO2, ZnO2 and Zr(WO4)2. All of the catalyst exhibited higher oil yield compared to non-catalytic process indicating high activity of the catalyst. The algae cell was easier to destroyed at supercritical condition, then segregated to polar and non-polar phase. The separation to these two phases was originated from heteroatom and aliphatic bond cracking as confirmed by elemental analysis that nitrogen and oxygen content reduced after treated with supercritical methanol. The catalyst role in this reaction was perceived to increase cracking of O- and N- compounds, thus increase the oil yield. 3 Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of algae-derived oils Algae–derived oils were associated with a wide range of chemical compounds and therefore must be upgraded to obtain high quality oils that are either rich of hydrocarbons or directly suitable for the applications in internal combustion engines [110]. Sequel to the complex composition characteristics, algae-derived oils were widely recognized as “biocrude oils” in the literature. Therefore, the term biocrude oil was applicable to describe complex composition of O-bearing compounds (i.e. the oxygenates) with different molecular weights. A part from the oxygenate compounds, N-derivatives such as amines (aliphatic and heterocyclic) and amides could be detected with reasonable concentration. Zhang et al. [111], has reported a typical composition of biocrude oil derived from algae feedstock via HTL with some homogeneous catalysts at 260–300 °C (see Fig. 6). Clearly, the detected compounds could be subdivided into different functionalities and distribution that was catalyst-dependent. The composition changed at various reaction temperatures. It could be observed that non-catalytic reaction produced mainly fatty acids and their derivatives. However, the introduction of catalysts (KOH and acetic acid) triggered a noticeable reduction in the concentration of fatty acids and alcohols. On the other hand, the composition of N-bearing compounds (including the heterocycles) increased with temperature changes from 260 to 300 °C. These specific observations on the compositions of algae-derived oils were also documented by many other research groups [112–116]. In general terms, non-refined algae oils were black, thickened liquids that has the potentials to exist as solids at room temperature and highly susceptible to separation from the aqueous phase after production [110]. GC-MS analyses showed that the elemental compositions of most oils were similar to those parent algae biomass. Hydrotreatment was a necessary step to upgrade the oils into more useful feeds that suitable for fuel applications. The hydrotreating process involved the use of certain temperature and pressure conditions to eliminate N-, O- and S-compounds from a given feed. The incorporation of H2 was necessary to improve the process efficiency. The common hydrotreating processes was hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) and hydrodesulfurization (HDS) for the removal of O-, N- and S-derivatives, respectively, from the fuel fraction. The HDO, as the main topic of this paper, was widely employed for biomass-based upgrading because most oils derived from biomass were rich in O-derivatives. Originally, the process was utilized for the conversion of vegetable oils and biodiesel into gasoline and diesel fuels [117,118]. The original feeds were associated with poor fuel characteristics including limited energy efficiency, poor stability properties and miscibility that different to the conventional fuel feeds. The most widely employed catalytic systems for the HDO reaction were Pd and Pt metals (even though Rh and Ru were also considered) doped over oxide supports like SiO2 and TiO2 or the composite oxides [117]. However, the scope was extended to cover other cheap transition metal catalysts based on Ni, Co and Mo with similar support systems [119–122]. Considering the wide exploitation of ZSM-5 and MOR zeolites as hydrotreating materials in petroleum refining, these catalysts were evaluated to the algae-based oils HDO application [123]. Irrespective to the selected catalyst, the introduction of sulfur was usually carried out to ensure activity and stability properties of the catalysts on stream [124,125]. For the purpose of this paper, the HDO of algae-derived oils would be covered initially for model compounds and later for real oil feeds. 3.1 HDO of model compounds in algae oils Proper understanding of the process chemistry occur during the HDO reaction, could better be achieved when specific model compounds were fundamentally considered. It is a known fact that the fatty acids represent a greater chemical composition of the algae-derived oils. Therefore, catalysts that suitable for HDO of fatty acids could potentially be good candidates for the real oil feeds. The HDO of fatty acid compounds proceeded with removal of water vapor (i.e. H2O(g)) and also CO and CO2 gases when hydrodecarboxylation and hydrodecarbonylation take place simultaneously with the HDO reaction [126]. The derivable products were mostly long chain hydrocarbons in the diesel and jet fuels range. Fatty acids commonly found in the algae oils include oleic, stearic, abietic and linoleic acids [127–130]. All of these compounds were long chain carbon derivatives with compatibilities to produce diesel range products following the HDO process. Recently, Ojagh and co-workers [126], performed the HDO of two fatty acid compounds (i.e. oleic and abietic) using a NiMo catalyst supported with alumina. The catalyst was developed via sequential impregnation technique that involved the incorporation of 5 and 15 wt.% of Ni and Mo, respectively. Their reaction results demonstrated that abietic acid could be converted 100% within 1 h at 320 °C, and similar results were earlier obtained by Bernas and co-investigators. The results further provided an insight into the HDO mechanism for abietic acid upgrading. Disproportionation reactions that initiated with hydrogenation and subsequent isomerization and dehydrogenation were substantially confirmed due to the detection of di- and de-hydroabietic acids as primary intermediates. Substituted trienes were therefore detected as the final reaction products in consistency with earlier results [131–133]. Ojagh et al. [126], further showed that the evaluation with oleic acid produced a complete conversion after 3 h under constant conditions. Therefore, the catalytic activity was also fatty acid dependent. However, in a similar trend to abietic acid conversion, reaction intermediates such as stearic acid that were products of dehydrogenation and isomerization, were initially detected before their final conversion into C17 C18 alkanes of the diesel range as presented in Fig. 7. Consistent with previous results [134–136], co-feeding of the two fatty acids (i.e. abietic and oleic) produced competitive reactions and consequently lowered the catalyst stability over reaction period. The main role of Mo species during the HDO reaction was investigated by Valencia and co-workers [137]. They prepared 12 wt.% Mo/SiO2 aided by impregnation with either citric or malonic acid in water. Fatty acid conversion was performed at 280 °C by the application of ∼5 MPa hydrogen pressure. It was established that the Mo species mainly catalyzed CO and COH ruptures over time following an initial hydrogenation of unsaturated bonds in the fatty acid. Accordingly, the catalyst that prepared via citric acid impregnation was more active by virtue to achieve higher Mo dispersion and the retention of catalytic structure. The participation of multi-valence Mo species (i.e. Mo4+, Mo5+and Mo6+) during the reaction was also substantiated in agreement with some earlier publications [138–140]. Arora et al. [122], studied the role of Fe species during HDO of fatty acids with NiMo/Al2O3 and Mo/Al2O3 materials. The catalytic investigations were carried out at 325 °C and 6 MPa pressure of hydrogen. Fe species were co-fed to both catalysts to identify their roles as either promoters or poisons to the active catalysts. The reaction data revealed that, irrespective of the catalyst nature, raising the concentrations of Fe species drastically reduced the formation of C17 and C18 hydrocarbons from oleic acid. The characterization data further showed that the deposition of Fe particles blocked the active sites of Ni and Mo species to be accessed by reaction feeds and intermediates. With both catalysts, the development of Fe-Mo and Fe-Ni hybrids accounted for substantial reduction in the catalytic performance over time. Therefore, it could be inferred that the choice of a co-metal for HDO catalyst design must be carried out with textural and metal-metal interaction feasibility considerations [141–143]. Apparently, reaction with NiMo/Al2O3 completed within the first 40 min. However, the addition of 2000 ppm Fe species produced only 7% for > 5 h. It also favored the formation of Fe-oleate instead of catalyzing the selectivity to the C17 and C18 hydrocarbon species. In addition to this fact, Arora et al. [122], further produced characterization results that confirmed the pore-blockage and concomitant reduction in active surface areas of both NiMo/Al2O3 and Mo/Al2O3 materials by at least 50% following the addition of 2000 ppm of Fe particles. Although the reaction mechanism was consistent to that of stearic acid intermediate formation and the decarboxylation of –COOH groups, C17 and C18 were the main reaction products detected in the absent of Fe species [144–146]. Overall, the competitive Fe-oleate formation drastically reduced the activities by 36 and 44% for NiMo/Al2O3 and Mo/Al2O3 materials, respectively. Arun et al. recently explored some catalysts support including γ -Al2O3, SBA-15 and hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS) to NiMo catalysts [147]. Although SBA-15 exhibited the largest surface area, but the optimum removal of oxygen from oleic acid (77%) was obtained by γ -Al2O3 inferring the crucial role of acid sites. The higher acidity of the support, the higher HDO activity of the catalyst. In another research, Ruangudomsakul et al. studied the incorporation of some metals such as Ni, Co and Cu to phosphide to produce green diesel from palm oil [148]. The catalysts were synthesized with precipitation method and became metal-phosphide after calcination and reduction with H2. The catalytic evaluation at 300, 350 and 400 ∘ C confirmed that Ni resulted to optimum green diesel yield (70%) at 350 °C after 6 h of reaction test. The reaction pathway was proposed via hydrogenation of double bonds by metal sites, then the CO bond was cracked by hydrogenolysis. Thus, the different affinity of metals for hydrogenation activity, differentiated the HDO result. Recently, Hachemi and Murzin [149], compared the activities of Pd/C and Ni/H-Y-80 materials for HDO reaction. They found that the two catalysts exhibit different roles. Although both materials produced similar conversions over time, the Ni/H-Y-80 was more selective to HDO reaction, while Pd/C mainly catalyzed decarboxylation and decarbonylation of the R-COOH and R-COOR compounds. Previously, some investigators found that supported Pd and Pt catalysts as more active to the formation of decarboxylation products over a range of temperature and pressure conditions [150–152]. Recently, Joen et al. [153], evaluated a range of Pt, Pd and Ru systems for oleic acid upgrading. The active particles were generally supported with Ce0.6Zr0.4O2. They found that the application of low hydrogen pressure as susceptible to the degrade the CC chains in oleic acid and the eliminate CO2 and CO gases via decarboxylation and decarbonylation reactions in consistency with earlier works [154,155]. However, when the catalysts were modified with Ni species, HDO reaction was also simultaneously observed. Among all the catalysts, Pt-Ni system exhibited the best catalytic activity with 99% conversion at 300 °C in < 1 h. It similarly produced the highest yield of C9 C17 hydrocarbons of 54%. Incorporation of the Ni particles created a synergic interaction with Pd, Pt and Ru species thereby elevating accessibility to reacting oleic acid molecules and the generated intermediates. Recently, Kochaputi et al. used Cu3P as a catalyst for deoxygenation of oleic acid at 340 ∘ C for 6 h [156]. This catalyst was prepared by reduction of metallic Cu (at 350 °C), then reacted with phosphorous precursor ((NH4)2HPO4) (at 600 °C). The in-situ XRD and in-situ XAS confirmed that CuP2 and Cu(OH)2 were intermediate compound before fully converted to Cu3P on the USY support. The oleic conversion reached 99% with the highest selectivity to aromatic compound (46%). A part from fatty acids, compounds such as carbonyls (i.e. aldehydes and ketones), simple organic acids and phenolic derivatives were appreciably found in algae-derived oils. Recently, studies have been conducted on the HDO of these compounds as model investigations. Dwiatmoko and co-workers [52], evaluated the role of Ru/W-Zr systems for guaiacol HDO. They found the best HDO activity of 97% with a catalyst containing 10 wt.% of W. Accordingly, Jiang et al. [157], conducted similar reaction using H-ZSM-5 catalysts having varied Si/Al ratios at the temperature range of 500–800 °C. They established zeolite-acidity as a key influential factor during the guaiacol HDO. The catalyst H-ZSM-5; Si/Al = 200) produced the highest selectivity to benzene and toluene (i.e. 2–3% higher than for all other catalysts). In addition to the effect of zeolite-acidity, raising the reaction temperature promoted guaiacol conversion, but increased the chances of catalyst deactivation by coking. The overall reaction pathway was consistent to that depicted in Fig. 3 . However, significant amount of BTEX was detected than cyclic alkanes. In their investigations, Zhang et al. [158], employed phenols as model compounds and Ni/SiO2 and Ni/Al2O3 as catalytic materials. They found that phenolic compounds could be upgraded yielding up to 90% of gasoline range hydrocarbons. The mechanism of the reaction involved an initial hydrogenation followed by CO cleavages, isomerization, dehydrogenation and protonic rearrangement. Recently, Yang et al. also used phenol as a model of bio-oil for HDO reaction with amphipathic catalyst consisted of Pd and carbon-silica alumina [159]. The reaction was conducted at 200 °C and 5 MPa H2 which yielded 88% selectivity to cyclohexane indicating good activity for HDO. From their studies, they revealed that the optimum distribution of oil/water interface of the catalyst contributed significantly to high activity for HDO. Li and co-workers [41], utilized M-modified Ni-based catalysts (M = Al, La and Ga) supported with H-ZSM-5 and H-BEA systems for HDO of different oxygenates. Reactions were conducted between 140 and 300 °C and 1.6 MPa of hydrogen. Among the alcohols, guaiacol produced 71% of fuel grade hydrocarbons with M-modified catalysts. Among these, aromatics were the dominant species due to the difficulty in ring ruptures. On the other hand, Ni/H-ZSM-5 modified with Al exhibited the best activity during acetic acid HDO, producing 89% of hydrocarbons. The same catalyst was also produced an optimal hydrocarbon content of 80% when the acetic acid was replaced with hydroxyacetone. Mechanistically, both acetic acid and hydroxyacetone were transformed via similar reaction pathways. The three key intermediary reactions involved include self-condensation, de-methylation and aldol condensation with subsequent production of long chain hydrocarbons. In another research, Xu et al., employed carbon-supported small content of noble metal (Ru) that coated to Co [160]. Guaiacol was also used as a model for HDO and the reaction was carried out at 200 °C and 1 MPa that produced 94% yield of cyclohexane. This study confirmed that Co in the catalyst formed more oxygen vacancies, while Ru decorated Co favored to hydrogenolysis reaction which then promoted excellent removal of oxygen. This result was similar to a research reported by Xiang et al. where Ru and Co work synergy to improve HDO activity [161]. DFT calculation revealed that good dispersion of Ru-Co in hexagonal structure and highly porous facilitated better hydrogen adsorption that led to easier hydrogen spillover. Shu and co-researchers [162], explored the effect of preparation option on the HDO performance of Pt/TiO2 systems for phenolic compounds conversion. Irrespective of the employed technique, the loading of Pt was adjusted to 2 wt.% and the catalytic evaluations was conducted at 280 °C for 4 h using 1 MPa hydrogen pressure. The order of the catalytic activity followed the trend Pt/TiO2 (SG) < Pt/TiO2 (S) < Pt/TiO2 (CO) < Pt/TiO2 (PC) (where SG = sol-gel, S = supported, CO = co-precipitated and PC = photochemical method of synthesis). Accordingly, catalyst developed via the photochemical method was more active and selective. It produced 99.9% conversion of guaiacol and 95% selectivity to cyclohexane. On the other hand, the sol-gel-prepared catalyst exhibited the least activity of 23 and 31% for conversion and selectivity, respectively. The catalytic trend was appreciably similar for seven other phenolic compounds evaluated under the same conditions. The exceptional activity of the Pt/TiO2 (PC) catalyst had been attributed to its highest dispersion characteristics than other designed catalysts. The same catalyst was also employed for repeated cycles of reaction with negligible deactivation, but also produced fuel range hydrocarbons with C6 C13 phenols. Feliczak et al. [163], used SBA-16 as the support material and compared the catalytic activity of Pt with other metals such as Ru, Nb and Pd during phenol upgrading at 90 to 130 °C and various H2 pressures in the range of 2.5 to 6 MPa. All the metal species were incorporated onto the SBA-16 support via incipient wetness impregnation method. The characterization results showed that the Nb-modified SBA-16 catalyst displayed the highest surface area and pore volume properties of 920 m2/g and 0.6 mL/g, respectively. However, as illustrated in Fig. 8 , the reaction pathway was the same for all the catalytic systems. Initial dehydrogenation of phenol ring produced cyclohexanol, which via dehydration became cyclohexane. Alternatively, a different route leading to 2,4-dimethylhexane formation could be followed. From the studied catalysts, Pt/SBA-16 showed the best catalytic activity due to better dispersion of Pt particles over the SBA-16 than other metals. This catalyst produced 100% phenol conversion with at least 75% yield of fuel bearing hydrocarbon (i.e. 2,4-dimethylhexane) under all the tested reaction conditions. Generally, metals supported with oxides, carbon and zeolite systems were currently considered for the upgrading of model compounds algae-derived oils via the HDO reaction. While the role of co-metalization, effects of catalyst preparation methods susceptible deactivation parameters and the mechanisms of disproportionation of specific model compounds have been established, there are several other issues that are still debatable in the literature [164–170]. Reliable details on the incorporation of noble metals such as Pt and Pd supported with carbon as HDO catalysts instead of hydrodecarboxylation and hydrodecarbonylation were still sketchy. Although the dispersion of Pt particles played important role during ketones and phenols HDO, the most appropriate support materials (i.e. zeolites or oxides) have not been fully identified. The specific role of support structure-acidity properties has also not been resolved yet. Other issues for consideration include the effect of co-presence of water and N-bearing compounds in the feed on catalytic performance and the choice of most appropriate reactor system. 3.2 HDO of real algae-derived oil feeds Clearly, the algae-derived oils are combination of several organic and organo-metallic compounds and are therefore more difficult to be hydrotreated than the model compounds. Typical oil can contain up to 15 wt.% of heteroatom-bearing derivatives [171]. Therefore, any catalyst design for HDO must take into cognizance specific parameters such as possibility of side reaction interference, complex composition of the feed and the nature of the final reaction products desired [172–175]. However, even with these concerns, the HDO process remained the most promising technology for upgrading the oils into fuel grade hydrocarbon compounds. At some instances hydrodenitrogenation (HDN), hydrodesulfurization (HDS) and demetalization processes are conducted simultaneously with the HDO such that metals, N- and S-compounds are eliminated together with the oxygenates [176–179]. Many studies have been documented so far in this in this direction, but this paper will focus on those that fit the designed objectives. Biller and co-researchers [178], conducted the HDO of oils derived from chlorella microalgae at the temperatures of 350–405 °C for 2 h in the presence of hydrogen (60–66 bar). The HDO products yield was generally dependent on the reaction conditions. At 405 °C, the concentration of hydrocarbons product reached 69% [180]. Accordingly, the two catalytic systems (i.e. NiMo and CoMo) produced optimal oxygenates reduction of 86 and 91%, respectively. Owing to the rich concentration of N-derivatives in the initial oil feed, HDN reaction occurred simultaneously with overall activity of 55–60% for the two catalysts. One unique feature of interest was that both catalytic materials exhibited appreciable stability for 2 h and were less-susceptible to the production of C1 C4 cracked hydrocarbons. In their own investigation, Bai and his co-researchers [181], evaluated several catalytic materials (i.e. more than 10) for HDO at higher than 200 °C using a batch-type reactor system. Ru/C and Raney-Ni proved as the most effective and produced gasoline and diesel range hydrocarbons in the range of 60–77%. Other catalysts however deactivated with time due to the effect of metals and active sites poisoning by the produced H2O and NH3 gases. Later Duan et al. [182], compared the hydrotreating efficiency of the Ru/C with that of Mo/C under constant conditions. Both catalysts were evaluated at 400 °C using 5 MPa hydrogen pressure for 4 h. While the separate catalysts produced ∼70% oxygenates removal, the mixture produced 90% of hydrocarbons in addition to the 59% of deoxygenated products. Their characterization data revealed a synergy between Ru and Mo particles as effective active sites poisoning and retarding carbonaceous deposition. Apparently, reactions with Mo/C alone decayed more rapidly due to poisoning effect than the Ru/C catalyst. These results could be compared to the findings of Elliot et al. [183], who employed Al2O3 supported CoMo for HDO reaction of a varieties of macroalgae-derived oils at 405 °C and 136 bar. However, the incorporation of Co species in the latter catalyst triggered a resistance of Mo particles to rapid deactivation. Haider et al. [171], investigated the effect of some reaction parameters (i.e. temperature, initial hydrogen pressure and time) during the HDO of oils derived from spirulina feedstock. The catalyst was NiMo supported with alumina. They revealed that increasing temperature from 250 to 350 °C, favored complete deoxygenation of oil with total selectivity to hydrocarbons. However, increasing hydrogen pressure shifted the reaction towards HDN than HDO. For instance, at 40 bar, the yield of HDN products was 47%, but reached 80% when the pressure was raised to 80 bar. However, irrespective of the reaction condition applied the hydrocarbons obtained were within the diesel and gasoline range. Guo et al. [184], screened a range of N-based catalysts for the hydrotreating of oils derived from chlorella and nannochloropsis. The reactions were conducted at two different temperatures (i.e. 250 and 400 °C) for 4 h. Their results as illustrated in Fig. 9 showed the reaction temperature and the presence of catalyst to exhibit an influential role during the process. For instance, at 250 °C, the conversion of oil was 10% because 90 wt.% of the oil remained for the non-catalytic process. However, the incorporation of catalyst triggered 46% conversion at 400 °C with a concomitant increased in the production of hydrocarbon products. The results similarly agreed to those of previous investigations [185,186]. Accordingly, when the temperature was elevated from 250 to 400 °C, HDN reaction occurred simultaneously with HDO. In their studies, CO and CO2 were main products at 250 °C, while C1 C4 were mainly observed at 400 °C. Therefore, while low temperature was mainly susceptible to hydrodecarbonylation and hydrodecarboxylation reactions, the 400 °C employed facilitated hydrogenation and hydrocracking processes. A summary of the roles of some metals supported oxides and carbon recently reported in the literature were documented in Table 2 . Sangnikul et al. [187], found that the incorporation of Cu and Ce particles to have a negative effect on the catalytic activity of a NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst. The conversion with unmodified catalyst reached up to 63% at 300 °C, but declined to 57 and 43% when Ce and Cu species were introduced, respectively. The consequential effects of metal modified catalyst was the blockage of the active NiMo surfaces and thereby reducing the accessibility to the reaction species in the algae-derived oil. According to Costanzo et al. [188], a Ru/C system catalyzed both HDO and HDN reactions at 225 °C that produced hydrocarbons with a range of gasoline, kerosene and gas oil. Jensen et al. [189], however showed that at very high H2/oil ratios of 846–966, hydrocarbon products could be derived over a wide range of reaction temperatures. According to Leng et al. [190], modification of a Ni/Al2O3 with Fe particles reduced the oxygenates content in algae-oil by 47.59%. This reduction can be described as low compared the details reported in other studies above. It can be attributed to the negative effect of the Fe particles. Xu and co-researchers [191], modified a Ni/CeO2 catalyst with Ru and evaluated the activity in HTL-derived oil valorization at 450 °C for 1 h. In this regard, the modification appeared positive because the yield of hydrocarbons was shifted from 72 to 80%. While many investigators concentrated on the application of metals and modified metal catalysts, recent interest was also shifted to the evaluation of zeolitic materials for the HDO reaction. For instance, Li and Savage [192], investigated protonic H-ZSM-5 at 400–500 °C and 5 MPa. In this case, increasing reaction temperature posed reduction in the yield of liquid hydrocarbons from 75 to 42%. It was confirmed that high temperatures have negative effect to trigger facile hydrocracking of the developed reaction products, thereby producing gaseous C1 C4 hydrocarbons. The zeolite materials were widely explored for biomass upgrading processes due to their special characteristics that differentiated them from other supports of the metal-based systems. They were well classified minerals attributed with susceptibility for ion-exchange as well as reversible dehydration phenomena [193–196]. Zeolites possessed framework structures associated with series of interconnected features that capable of accommodating significant number of cationic metal species. Owing to these unique structural features, zeolites can be designed to different grades and applied in the reaction of interest [197–200]. A part from the chances for structural modifications, zeolites could be synthesized with different acidity scales by incorporating metals, changing the Si/Al ratio or ion-exchange [201,202]. While abundant natural zeolites were easily obtained globally, their commercial production remained attractive by virtue of their diverse applications. Regarding the algae-derived oils hydrotreating by HDO, zeolites were explored to mainly ascertain how the structural-acidity properties proffered selectivity to fuel range hydrocarbons with hindering deactivation [203,204]. Duan and co-workers [205], evaluated a range of zeolite catalysts including H-BEA, H-ZSM-5 and H-Y systems in comparison to a SAPO-11 material for the upgrading of algae-derived oils. Although the catalysts were active to HDO, HDN and HDS reactions, the H-Y and H-ZSM-5 catalysts of comparable acidity produced similar conversions and selectivity to hydrocarbon products. However, the H-SAPO-11 deactivated faster due to its low carbonaceous deposits tolerance. According to the characterization results, micropores were higher in H-Y and H-ZSM-5 catalyst compared to H-SAPO-11. On the other hand, H-MCM-41 composed mainly of mesopores that substantially surpassed the chance of deactivation by coking and increased the possibility of yielding heavier hydrocarbon products in the diesel range. The H-SAPO-11 catalyst that exhibited the least pore sizes experienced a pronounced pore-blockage because the in situ generated carbon deposits became difficult to diffuse through the pores. The work of Cole et al. [206], involved the hydrotreating of oil derived from fresh water feedstock (i.e. oedogonium algae) using SAPO-11 catalysts. The results were compared with those NiMo and Ru/C catalysts. At low temperature and pressure, these catalysts were less-active despite the low concentration of oxygenates and N-compounds in the oil feed. On the other hand, although a Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst deactivated over time, it produced 96% of liquid hydrocarbon products at 360 °C. While the production of C1 C4 hydrocarbons was limited due to low catalyst acidity, the amounts of oxygenates and aromatics in the initial oil feed reduced considerably. 4 The role of sulfidation on HDO catalysts The literature documented above indicated some metallic catalysts especially those of Ni, Co and Mo to deactivate over time or exert low activities under certain reaction conditions. The activity evolution over time occurred due to crystal changes during reaction period. The introduction of sulfur could maintain the catalyst structure, but the HDO activity reduced as a result of competitive adsorption and increasing possibility for sulfur contamination to the extracted bio-crude oil. The sulfidation approach proceeded with the introduction of sulfur species into the catalyst precursor with the aid of appropriate sulfiding agent under controlled temperature and pressure conditions [207–209]. It has been established that heating a sulfiding agent with hydrogen gas caused its decomposition and consequently generates H2S that is necessary for the overall sulfidation of the catalyst. Although several other sulfiding agents are available today, compounds such as dimethylsulfide and t-butylpoly sulfide were regularly utilized by industries as sulfiding agents [210–214]. However, in common laboratory applications, hydrogen sulfide gas can directly be introduced into the prepared catalyst bed. The choice of a suitable sulfiding agent was also dependent on its specific properties. Dimethylsulfide has attracted much research attention owing to the fact that it could be produced cheaply and generated high sulfur content. Its ability to undergo a two-steps decomposition was beneficial in inhibiting exothermic reaction that commonly occur during sulfidation process. On the other hand, the application of t-butylpoly sulfide was considered, especially at low temperature decomposition. Proper sulfidation of any metal-supported catalyst was a vital factor in obtaining excellent catalytic performance. Certainly, the sulfidation procedure varies according to the industry, laboratory or catalyst system and hydrotreatment reaction under consideration. However, the generally accepted fact was that the textural, morphological and activity properties of the sulfided catalysts were generally more promising than of the non-sulfided catalysts. An EXAFS investigation by Cattaneoet al. [215], showed that when MoO3/SiO2 was sulfided the transient stage involved the formation of oxysulfide species which later transformed into MoS2/SiO2 species. Similarly, the formation of MoS3-like products could be detected. On the other hand, the results further showed that NiO was first converted into Ni species and later the sulfide particles. They also found the utilization of chelating agents such as ethylenediamine and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid during initial catalyst precursor preparation as very beneficial in facilitating the sulfidation process and consequently the net hydrotreating activity. Villarreal and co-researchers [216], studied the effect of heating rate on the extent of sulfide formation with a composite catalyst (i.e. NiMo supported with SiO2-Al2O3). They found a chelating agent (i.e. citric acid) as a good candidate to increase the formation of MoS2 species of low crystalline sizes at moderate to high temperatures of sulfidation. Accordingly, the hydrotreating activity was enhanced. Studies by a number of other investigators [217–221], showed complete sulfidation as a mandatory factor for designing an active and stable catalyst. Clearly, all sulfidation procedures that proceed with metal oxides transformation into the sulfide phase were more promising techniques. They also demonstrated that although high temperature conditions were important in triggering Mo-O-Mo breakages and the net formation of MoS2 species, sintering of active particles with consequential activity-decay could be very prominent. These observations suggested a gradual heating rate application to be the most accepted procedure considered today. Meanwhile, Hidalgo-herrador et al. substituted formic acid with oxalic acid to produce hydrogen using commercial HDO catalyst and showed high yield of deoxygenated oil from waste cooking oil [222]. During algae-derived oils HDO with Ni and Mo-based catalysts, sulfidation was usually employed to retard the possibility of catalyst deactivation by coking as well as to increase activity to an optimum grade. Several works have compared the performance of both sulfided and non-sulfided catalytic systems. Table 3 provides a documentation on the role of sulfidation on the catalytic performance of some HDO catalysts reported in the literature. Vo et al. [223], performed a range of HDO reactions with non-sulfided catalysts based on Mo modified with Al2O3 and TiO2 support systems. Although the catalytic activity reached up to 100%, it showed rapid deactivation due to non-sulfidation. The sulfide species were required to prevent coking and side reaction interferences. Popov and co-workers [224], found a sulfided CoMo supported with silica-alumina as more active and stable than the non-sulfided counterpart. It produced a well-stabilized 100% conversion for 1 h period compared to 74% conversion for the non-sulfided catalyst that deactivated with time. According to He and Wang [225], both CoMo/Al2O3 and NiMo/Al2O3 were more active, stable and selective for 2 h when sulfided. These materials produced >90% yields of hydrocarbons in addition to complete conversion of oil. Yang et al. [226], reported the sulfidation of CoMo/MgO catalyst at 400 °C for 4 h to have a beneficial effect on its overall catalytic stability, but further demonstrated a P-modified CoMo/MgO catalyst as more active and stable. Hong et al. [227], compared the activities of a range of Pt-doped catalysts with that of CoMo/Al2O3 (sulfided). All catalysts produced closely similar conversions of 100% with selectivity to hydrocarbon products and stable throughout the reaction period. Mortensen et al. investigated the effect of impurities such as Cl, S, and K to Ni-MoS2 activity in hydrodeoxygenation of mixture of 1-octanol and phenol [228]. Although the catalyst stability was maintained with exposure of impurities, but the obtained bio-oil contained sulfur compound such as thiol, especially under low residence time. The amount of sulfur flow need to be enhanced at high water content due to removal of sulfur edge by oxygen from water. They revealed that chlorine have higher tendency to bind with active sites of MoS2, thus destructed the catalytic activity, but restored after removing chlorine from the feed. On contrary, potassium (K) deactivated the catalytic performance permanently until only less than 5% degree of deoxygenation due to penetration of K to vacancy sites of MoS2, thus blockade the active sites. From all of these studied sulfide catalyst, it was confirmed that the catalyst required sulfur feed, thus make the process unfavorable from economic and environment perspective. 5 Peculiarities of phosphorous modification Phosphorous modification is another alternative to improve HDO performance. Metal that modified with phosphide improved proton transfer ability and created new active sites that increased feedstock dispersion to the catalyst. This catalyst form promoted decarboxylation and dehydrogenation with similar activity to noble metals. However, too high phosphorous contents tend to agglomerate and decreased the catalytic activity [229]. The introduction of transition metal-phosphide catalyst for the hydrotreating of the derived oils and corresponding model compounds. It is a common science that phosphorous compounds can react with metals to yield phosphides of wide range of structures, activity and stability properties in different catalysis processes [230–232]. Although almost all the metals known today interacted with phosphorous to form the phosphide compounds, those transition metals (i.e. MP and M2P; M = metal) and the supported derivatives were more recognized for HDO and other hydrotreating applications. It has been widely acknowledged in the literature that the activities of the metal phosphide systems were connected to their structures illustrated in Fig. 10 [233]. Accordingly, the chemistry of the preparations, structural elucidations and their link with other compounds such as carbides and nitrides have been substantially documented by a good number of publications [234–237]. Therefore, the current review laid emphasis on their role during HDO reaction of oils derived from algae and the associated model compounds. Their activities were dependent to the nature of the feed, catalyst synthesis procedures as well as the reaction conditions [238–242]. Recently, Ly and co-researchers [243], conducted HDO reactions with two hybrid phosphides (i.e. Fe2P and Ni2P) doped over alumina particles. The catalysts were evaluated in the hydrotreating of substituted furan and oil derived from saccharina algae. The loadings of phosphide particles were varied between 5 and 15 wt.% and the resulted catalysts calcined at temperatures in the range of 500–800 °C. The catalysts were found to exhibit pore volume and pore sizes in the ranges of 0.26–0.48 mL/g and 4.21–5.75 nm, respectively. For the test reactions performed with Fe2P/Al2O3 catalyst calcined at 500 °C, the catalytic activity and selectivity to fuel hydrocarbon products were dependent on the Fe2P loadings. For instance, increasing P loading from 5 to 15 wt.%, reduced conversion from 85% to 58%. Accordingly, the 5 wt.% Fe2P/Al2O3 produced the highest yield of fuel range hydrocarbons (i.e. > 84%). While the low Fe2P loadings were beneficial in achieving high dispersion of particles over the alumina support, higher loadings formed agglomerates of particles that deactivated quickly. On the other hand, catalysts calcined at 600 °C produced the best activity of 93% conversion and >86% yield of hydrocarbon product, respectively. A similar trend was observed with the Ni2P catalyst. Accordingly, the overall results agreed with some previous findings [244–247]. Yun et al. [248], studied the HDO using NiMo phosphides. The selected model compound was ɣ-valerolactone (a ketone common in most oil feeds). The active Ni-Mo-P phase was doped over H-MCM-41 as support and evaluated at temperatures of 200 to 350 °C in the presence of 0.5 MPa hydrogen. The reactions were also repeated with doped Ni2P and MoP catalysts at the same conditions. Generally, conversion increased with increasing temperature. For instance, at 250 °C, the conversion was 14% for the Ni-Mo-P/H-MCM-41 catalyst but increased to 99% at 350 °C and also stable. On the other hand, the yield of hydrocarbon products was nearly constant between 96 and 100% for all the studied catalysts and temperatures. The excellent activity-stability properties were attributed to low loadings of the active phases onto the H-MCM-41 support. Zhao et al. [249], developed several NiFeP/SiO2 materials in order to establish the main active sites in the Ni2P/SiO2 hydrotreating material. The Fe/Ni ratios were varied between 0 and 3. According to their results, all the catalysts showed excellent activity and selectivity at 3.1 MPa and 340 °C. Accordingly, the Fe and Ni particles homogenously interacted to form Fe-Ni-P species with enhanced activities. The active Ni(II) sites could be replaced by Fe(II) species and participate substantially at the hydrogenation stages of the reaction. Similarly, the Ni(II) sites was not replaced by Fe(II) particles and therefore performed other intermediary reactions during the hydrotreating reaction [250,251]. According to Vatituna et al. [252], the best way to incorporate the P particles into NiMo, CoMo or the NiFe catalyst was by the introduction of the P particles into the impregnation solution at the early stage of catalyst synthesis. This way, highly active phosphide particles with resistance to deactivation would be generated. Wu and co-workers [253], explored the role of P compositions in Ni2P catalytic systems by changing the Ni/P ratios during guaiacol upgrading via HDO. The Ni/P compositions were varied between 1 and 3, and SiO2 particles were incorporated as the support. While the dispersion of the Ni2P particles increased with reduction in the Ni/P ratio, the active surface area and particle sizes declined. For instance, when the Ni/P ratio was 3, the dispersion was 5.3% but increased to 9.4% when the Ni/P ratio was reduced to 1. On the other hand, the particle size reduced from 18.9 to 10.6 nm when the Ni/P ratio was reduced from 3 to 1. According to the reaction data, guaiacol conversion increased with increased in the Ni/P ratio. When Ni/P ratio was 1, the conversion was 93%, then increased to 94 and 99.8% at ratio of 2 and 3, respectively. However, reverse was the case for the yield of hydrocarbon products such as benzene and its derivatives. In terms of catalyst deactivation by coking, the amount of carbonaceous materials increased at high Ni/P ratios thereby reducing the catalytic stability. The mechanistic reaction over phosphorous modification to several transition metals was reported by Jain et al. using DFT calculation [254]. They studied three types of catalysts namely FeMoP, RuMoP and NiMoP using phenol as a model compound. The partial charge of metal and phosphorous contributed to CO elongation that can be used as a descriptor to activation energy. They revealed that FeMoP preferred to cleavage the CO bond, while RuMoP and NiMoP favored to ring hydrogenation which are the same with experimental selectivity result. Multifunctional catalyst was also explored for HDO reaction with phosphide modification. Tan et al. used Ni2P/Zr-SBA-15 as a catalyst to convert Jatropha oil directly to jet fuel range [255]. Zr was loaded simultaneously with SBA-15 synthesis and followed by impregnation with Ni and P precursor. These mixtures were then formed ZrP and Ni2P, thus improve the catalytic activity. The HDO evaluation at 45 Bar of hydrogen and 330 °C, produced 80% aliphatic compound in the range of C8 C16. From the product distribution, it was confirmed that the catalyst favored deoxidation, aromatization and cracking. This result would open plethora of interest for one step hydrodeoxygenation of fatty acids paraffin with low cost transition metals. 6 Stability of catalysts in water/steam: hydrothermal HDO The application of hydrothermal conditions can be very attractive in algae-derived oils HDO and allied biomass valorization [256–259]. However, appropriate control of the catalyst stability under these conditions was critical to handling negative reaction results. In zeolite catalyst, the rupture of Si-O-Al species via facile hydrolysis in water or steam was a serious issue that affect the zeolite stability. According to Ravenelle et al. [260], who explored the stability features of some synthetic zeolite frameworks (H-ZSM-5 and H-Y), the structural features could be degraded under hydrothermal conditions thereby limiting the overall catalytic activity. Their research employed steam generated between 150 and 200 °C for zeolites treatment for a period of 6 h. Both catalysts exhibited Si-O-Si bonds rupture that was also framework dependent. Specifically, the H-Y zeolite exhibited more degradation characteristics that increased with increasing zeolite acidity. Reduction of catalyst crystallinity was observed over time of hydrothermal treatment. They concluded that zeolites with low Si/Al ratios (i.e. high acidity) was more susceptible to hydrolysis under hydrothermal conditions. Another study by Bakare and his co-researchers [261], showed a pronounced degradation of Si-O-Al species with MTT frameworks when hydrothermally treated at 200 °C for 72 h. In addition to the reduction in zeolitic acidity by more than 0.1 mmol/g, the active surface area experienced a concomitant declination with time of treatment due to Si-Al species leaching. Several other investigators [262–266], reported variable degrees of instability with zeolite-based catalysts under hydrothermal conditions. A part from the zeolite-based catalysts, hydrothermal instability of selected systems based on transition metals (i.e. Ni, Co, Mo, Pd, Ru, Pt, etc.) supported with oxides have also been documented [267–269]. Ravenelle et al. [270], showed Al2O3-based catalysts to deactivate as a result of conversion to boehmite phase, which in turn caused Lewis acidity reduction and surface area collapse. They, however demonstrated that the destruction to these properties could significantly be inhibited when appropriate loadings of the metals (like Pt, Ni, etc.) were employed. This way, the metals provide protection to the surface –OH groups of the Al2O3 while catalyzing the reaction on interest. The findings were also in agreement with those later and earlier reported [271–273]. Jun et al. [274], developed several Pd/Nb2O5 catalysts and evaluated their hydrothermal features during hexanediol HDO at 250 °C and 5.5 MPa of hydrogen. They found good metal-support interactions to be responsible for the retention of physico-chemical properties of the catalysts. The HDO results showed hexanediol conversions between 88.5 and 97.5% with corresponding hexane selectivities between 18.6 and 38.9%. In agreement with earlier results [239,275–278], catalysts for hydrothermal HDO must be modified with acidic supports to ensure retention of structural integrity and achieve optimal conversion. Accordingly, the bifunctionality allowed the process to take place through three reaction modes that include CO ruptures through dehydration on the acidic functions, hydrogenation of CC and CO bonds on the metallic surfaces and CC ruptures were aided by sequential dehydration-decarbonylation processes. Generally, hydrothermal HDO of oils could be achieved with stability control when the catalyst design procedures and experimental conditions were carefully selected. One unique feature adopted recently in the literature was the in situ synthesis of hydrogen for the hydrothermal HDO process. During the normal HDO reaction, H2 was commonly employed at elevated pressures to facilitate oil conversion, which necessitate the requirement of advanced facilities and serious safety considerations. These factors attributed to the in situ option for the hydrothermal HDO process. Appropriate water-solvent ratios could be employed during the process to attain maximum catalytic efficiency. Solvents such as simple alcohols and organic acids (e.g. HCOOH, MeOH, EtOH, etc.) could be used in this regard. In their work, Mao et al. [279], conducted hydrothermal HDO of triglyceride ester derived from algae using Pd/C catalyst containing 5 wt.% Pd. The reaction was conducted by incorporating different solvent/water ratios in the range of 0:100 to 90:10 at 250 °C for 12 h. The results indicated that a competitive reaction could be observed depending on the solvent used. Although dodecane produced 100% conversion at all the solvent/water ratios, the selectivity was shifted towards oleic and steric acids formation rather than hydrocarbons because hydrolysis of esters was faster than HDO at low solvent/water ratios, but the yield of diesel-range hydrocarbon products increased reaching 52% at high ratios like 70/10 (dodecanal to water). Among the solvents utilized, decalin produced the highest hydrocarbons yield of 71.91% at the decalin to water ratio of 90/10. While the influence of in situ generated hydrogen was considered positive in terms of catalytic activity, the Pd/C catalyst was stable at all water/solvent ratios due to appropriate loading (i.e. 5 wt.%) of Pd particles. Yang et al. [280], conducted the reaction using zero-valent Al for oil upgrading under variable conditions. Specifically, aqueous phase was varied between 1:25 to 2:25 gmL−1 for the metal to phase ratio. This way, in situ hydrogen required for HDO was produced. The oil conversion was 100% and 76.38% optimum yield of hydrocarbons. Despite the extreme temperature of 500 °C employed, the catalyst was stable for the 2 h reaction period. Accordingly, the characterization results showed a retention of physico-chemical properties of the catalyst. Li et al. [281], developed a series of Ni-based catalysts via sequential precipitation techniques. The catalysts containing 60 wt.% of Ni in each case included Ni/LaO, Ni/AlSiO and a range of Ni/LaAlSiO systems possessing variable loadings of La/Si ratios. For the hydrothermal treatment, the developed catalysts were subjected to 8 h heating at 150 °C and the HDO reactions conducted using 4 MPa H2 pressure at variable temperatures and space velocities. The results of hydrothermal treatment showed only a slight reduction in the Ni content due to the incorporation of La and Si species which provided stabilization effects. In agreement with these results, Li et al. [282], previously demonstrated a Ni/AlSiO system to be more appreciably stable than Ni/Al2O3 when hydrothermally treated at 90 °C. The latter catalyst was rapidly hydrated into Al(OH)3 species. In addition to retention of Ni loadings, Li et al. [281], further showed that the acidity-basicity properties of the various Ni/AlSiO and Ni/LaAlSiO systems were retained following the hydrothermal treatment. Among all catalysts, Ni/LaAlSiO systems exhibited 95–99% HDO conversions with equivalent yields of hydrocarbon products. Therefore, the incorporation of La and Si together was not only positive towards catalyst stabilization, but also contributed to acidity-basicity retention and activity enhancement. According to some previous publications [283–285], modification of SiO2 and Al2O3 supports with La stabilized the surface by hindering structural collapse/transition and/or diffusion of active particles. This approach was then improved the catalyst hydrothermal stability. In addition to the incorporation of metals such as La, Si, Al, Ce, Nd, Eu, etc., structural and acidity stabilization during hydrothermal HDO, there were other potential approaches that have yielded promising results in related biomass-based and hydrotreating reactions. These include fluoride synthesis and silane treatment and more applicable to the zeolite-based catalysts [286–289]. These category of catalysts (i.e. the zeolites) could be prepared using the fluoride media by changing the ratio of fluoride and silica species. The introduction of fluoride ions provided an appropriate replacement of the OH− derivatives in the zeolites and consequently favor stability under water/steam (i.e. hydrothermal) conditions [290,291]. This way, the ruptures of Si-O-Si and Si-O-Al functions in the zeolite-frameworks could be substantially inhibited. In this regard, Jon et al. [292], developed a range of H-BEA systems possessing variable Si/Al ratios and upgraded them using NH4F media to generate the fluorided-catalysts. Hydrothermal stability tests conducted up to 1000 °C revealed a retention of the structure-acidity properties for the F−-modified catalysts, but a rapid degradation of the F−-free H-BEA zeolite. In terms of silane treatment, Zapata and co-researchers [293], examined some selected silane derivatives as synthetic modifiers for H-USY (Si/Al = 30). These materials ensured retention of pore volume, acidity and surface areas after hot water treatment at 200 °C for 24 h. In a related development, Khalil et al. [294], found that the silylation treatment contributed to stable conversion-selectivity properties during heavy oil hydrotreating at 470 °C for 4 h. Therefore, shifting the trend towards hydrothermal HDO application will escalate the process feasibility. The potential catalyst that can go to industrial scale was Ni2P supported on α-Al2O3 modified by SiO2 [295]. This catalyst was prepared by impregnation of Ni to α-Al2O3, then mixed to hydrothermal gel composition of SiO2. In this study, SiO2 acted as a spacer to inhibit phosphorous loss due to interaction between water and Ni2P. This catalyst exhibited 99% conversion of soybean oil to C15–18 paraffin and stable until 144 h which is three times higher than in absence of SiO2. 7 Conclusions and outlook Hydrothermal liquefaction is a potential method for extraction of oil from algae. This bio-crude oil has high oxygen content that unfavorable in fuel characteristic. Thus, hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reaction is increasingly becoming a major alternative for the elimination of oxygenates from algae-derived oils in a way to improve the fuel quality of the oils in compatible to conventional fuels. The literature documented in this paper indicated that a lot of research has been executed in the area with greater emphasis to catalyst design, selection of reaction conditions and the influence of oil-composition in deriving gasoline or diesel grade hydrocarbons. So far, there are certain parameters that have been fully resolved. The HDO catalysis mapping during last five years as presented in Fig. 11 revealed that Pd and Ni as the main catalyst. Ni based catalyst with sulfide and phosphide modification using zeolite and metal oxide as support compete with Pd based catalyst. The role of H2 pressure and the influence of zeolite textural-acidity properties on products yield. Ni based catalysts were more susceptible to HDO, while noble metal such as Pd systems were prominent in catalyzing hydrodecaronylation and hydrodecarboxylation. In all cases, the main reactions involved were those leading to CO, COH and CC cleavages depending on the catalyst composition and applied reaction conditions. On the other hand, high H2 pressure was required to favor HDO than catalytic cracking and in situ H2 production has a greater positive effect on the hydrocarbons yield than when external H2 source was considered. Zeolite catalysts were good candidates for not only HDO, but also catalyzing isomerization and mild hydrocracking thereby enhancing the production of light gasoline hydrocarbons. However, acidity control remained a key issue to be considered. The role of sulfidation in handling Ni-based catalysts deactivation by coking or impurities in the feed has also been resolved. In addition to active sites modification, the sulfide systems protected the catalyst surface from destructive effects of coke precursors or N- and S-compounds that can be found in the oil feed. Transition metal phosphides have been explored in this direction with Ni2P, MoP and Fe2P supported with oxides exhibiting the best catalytic activities so far. They were more active than commercial NiMo-catalysts and could be more stable than the sulfided catalysts. Other issues resolved include the effect of hydrothermal HDO conditions on catalyst stability, the influence of catalyst preparation procedure on the HDO of model compounds and the effect of low-to-high pressure on the overall activity-selectivity properties of sulfided NiMo and CoMo catalysts. Despite the above progress achieved in algae-derived oils HDO, there are key issues that should be explored in order to raise the prospects of HDO as an industrial process. In the production of diesel-range hydrocarbons, cracking remained a challenge because it shifts the reaction towards lighter products (including gases). Therefore, considering zeolite catalysts design in the hierarchical and/or nanoscale will be very important. These zeolite design was beneficial in reducing unwanted facile cracking and the elimination of diffusion problems in related reactions. Although sulfidation and phosphide synthesis were favorable, the literature has not fully establish the most appropriate sulfiding and phosphiding agents. Similarly, the concentration of sulfur or phosphorous required to attain optimal activity. In terms of hydrothermal HDO, zeolites design in the fluoride media and the consideration of organic silanes during synthesis are other areas for exploration. In addition to possibility of enhancing catalyst-hydrothermal stability, the overall HDO activity could be escalated. The reaction mechanisms developed so far were mainly applicable to the specific model compounds. Therefore, new investigations that can identify competing reactions occur in the real oil feeds were crucial toward escalating the understanding of process chemistry. Another issue of interest is the reactor design. Different reactor configurations should be evaluated to establish the most suitable design under specific reaction conditions. When these parameters are fully investigated and challenges resolved, the HDO process will greatly contribute in handling the lingering energy challenges. coredata.dc:description: Sequel to the future challenges identified in the energy indicators, the exploration of algae-biomass resources increasingly becoming an issue of interest. Algae-derived oils are accordingly considered as alternative fuels with great future prospects. However, their direct utilization is scientifically difficult due to associated complex compositions. So far, hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of the oils is increasingly viewed as the reliable upgrading process for deriving high quality fuels. The paper therefore explored and critically examined substantial literature on the updates related to catalyst design and testing for HDO, the influence of oil production techniques on its susceptibility to HDO, effects of parameters such as catalyst sulfidation, modification to phosphides, nature of support systems and preparation versus reaction conditions. In addition to highlights on reaction mechanisms, the paper also discussed the effect of hydrothermal treatment on HDO catalyst stability and provided insights into areas for further investigations.
coredata.dc:title: Towards sustainable catalysts in hydrodeoxygenation of algae-derived oils: A critical review
